Again, observe external phenomena. At the time of the seed, the time of the sprout, the time of the stem, the time of the leaf, the time of the flower, and the time of the fruit, these times are each different. I have heard that the gods are fully endowed with extremely wonderful bliss and spiritual powers, but they also have the five characteristics. Therefore, know that they are impermanent.

I have also heard that at the beginning of the eon, there were sentient beings who were each fully endowed with supreme wonderful virtues. Their bodies emitted light that illuminated themselves without the need for sun or moon. Due to the power of impermanence, the light disappeared and their virtues diminished.

I have also heard that in the past there was a wheel-turning sage king who ruled the four continents, accomplished the seven treasures, and attained great freedom, but he was unable to destroy the characteristics of impermanence.

If a bodhisattva is able to see the arising and ceasing impermanence of all dharmas in a single thought, this is called a bodhisattva perfecting the notion of impermanence.

The wise one, having cultivated the notion of impermanence, is able to distance himself from the conceit of permanence, the inversion of permanence, and the inversion of thought.

The wise further contemplate that birth is suffering, cessation is suffering, and because of the arising and cessation of suffering, it is impermanent, not the self or what belongs to the self.

The wise further contemplate that suffering is precisely impermanence, and impermanence is precisely suffering. If suffering is impermanent, how can the wise say there is a self?

If in the world there is not a single place where one can escape birth, old age, sickness, and death, how can I take pleasure in the world?
In the world, there is no progress without retrogression. Therefore, the world is definitely impermanent. If it is impermanent, how can a wise person take pleasure in the world?

Each and every sentient being, having gone through all the worlds, experiences both suffering and happiness. Although they may attain the body of a Brahma Heaven, up to the Heaven of Neither Perception nor Non-Perception, when their life ends they fall back into the three evil paths.

Although they may become the body of the Four Heavenly Kings, up to the Heaven of Freely Partaking of Others' Pleasures, when their life ends they are born in the animal realm, becoming a lion, tiger, leopard, wolf, elephant, horse, or ox.

Next, contemplate the body of a wheel-turning sage king, who rules the four continents, is powerful and self-sufficient, but when his blessings are exhausted, he becomes poor and destitute, unable to obtain clothing and food.
The wise one deeply contemplates such matters and gives rise to the thought that the world is not enjoyable.

The wise one further contemplates the dharmas in the world, namely houses, clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, incense, flowers, necklaces, various kinds of music, wealth, and valuables. Such things are all for the purpose of leaving behind suffering;
but the essence of these things is suffering itself. How can one use suffering to leave behind suffering?
Good man!
The wise one, having contemplated in this way, does not give rise to attachment and the thought of enjoyment towards worldly things.
Good man!

It is like a person whose body is afflicted with a serious illness. Even if there are various kinds of music, singing and dancing, incense, flowers, and necklaces, they will never give rise to greed, attachment, or enjoyment towards them.
The wise one, having contemplated, is also like this.
Good man!

The wise deeply contemplate that all worldly realms are not places of refuge, not places of liberation, not places of tranquility, not lovable places, not places of the other shore, and are not the dharmas of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. If I were to delight in such a world, how could I attain liberation from these dharmas?
It is like a person who does not enjoy being in darkness but seeks light, yet returns to darkness again. Darkness is the world, and light is beyond the world.

If I delight in the world, it increases darkness and distances me from light. Darkness is ignorance, and light is the wisdom of illumination. The cause of this wisdom of illumination is precisely the notion of the unlovability of the world.
Although all the bonds of craving are fetters, I now crave for the wisdom of illumination and do not crave for the world.
The wise deeply contemplate such dharmas and fully possess the notion of the unlovability of the world.
Good man!
The wise person, having already cultivated the notion of the unlovability of the world, next cultivates the notion of death and observes.
This life is always surrounded by innumerable enemies, diminishing moment by moment, without any increase.

Like a mountain torrent that cannot remain still, like morning dew that cannot remain long, like a prisoner going to the market, step by step approaching death, like a cow or sheep being led to the slaughterhouse.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
How do the wise contemplate the moment-to-moment cessation?
The Buddha said: Good man!
It is like four people, all skilled in archery, gathered in one place, each shooting in one direction, all thinking:
'The four of us will shoot at the same time and fall at the same time.'
Then another person thinks:
'As long as the four arrows have not yet fallen, I can catch them all at once with my hand.'
Good man!
Can this person be said to be fast or not?
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
Yes, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
Good man!

Earth-bound ghosts are faster than this person, flying ghosts are faster than earth-bound ghosts, the Four Heavenly Kings are faster than flying ghosts, the sun and moon gods are faster than the Four Heavenly Kings, the swift and firm gods are faster than the sun and moon, and the lifespans of sentient beings are faster than the swift and firm gods.
Good man!
In one breath and one blink, the lifespans of sentient beings go through four hundred births and deaths.
If the wise are able to contemplate life in this way, this is called being able to contemplate the moment-to-moment cessation.
Good man!
The wise contemplate that life is under the control of the king of death. If I am able to escape from such a king of death, then I will be able to permanently sever the impermanent life.

Furthermore, the wise contemplate this life as being like a tree on a riverbank about to fall, like a person who has committed a grave offense and is about to be executed with no mercy, like a lion king when extremely hungry, like a poisonous snake when inhaling a great wind, like a thirsty horse when guarding water, like a greatly evil ghost when enraged - the king of death is also like this.
Good man!
If the wise are able to contemplate in this way, this is called cultivating the thought of death.
Good man!

The wise further contemplate, 'If I now leave the household life and obtain a lifespan of seven days and nights, I will diligently cultivate the path, uphold the precepts, expound the Dharma, and benefit sentient beings during that time.' This is called the wise cultivating the thought of death.

If I can obtain six days, five days, four days, three days, two days, one day, one hour, up to the time of an out-breath and an in-breath, I shall diligently cultivate the path, uphold the precepts, and benefit sentient beings by teaching the Dharma. This is called the wise one's good cultivation of the thought of death.
The wise one, being endowed with the above six thoughts, is the cause of the seven thoughts.
What are the seven?

First, the thought of constant cultivation; second, the thought of blissful cultivation; third, the thought of non-hatred; fourth, the thought of non-envy; fifth, the thought of good vows; sixth, the thought of non-arrogance; seventh, the thought of mastery in samÄdhi.
